DataElement.preferredName: Breast Asymptomatic Malignant Neoplasm Present Sum Longest Diameter Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the sum of measured or computed lengths of a straight line passing through the center of a circle and connecting two points on the circumference of a tumor, that has not produced any signs or symptoms of disease, composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues in one of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the presence of a tumor, that has not produced any signs or symptoms of disease, composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues in one of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest._Having no signs or symptoms of disease.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Concepts.definition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having no signs or symptoms of disease.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: Without clinical signs or indications that raise the possibility of a particular disorder or dysfunction.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the sum of measured or computed lengths of a straight line passing through the center of a circle and connecting two points on the circumference.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements, including linear dimensions, volume, and weight, of a patient's tumor.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Having the greater length of two or the greatest length of several.:Dimension; the magnitude of something in a particular direction, especially length or width or height.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: Having the greater length of two or the greatest length of several.
The magnitude of something in a particular direction, especially length or width or height.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.
